results.title: The Overlanders [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Dilys Powell, a film critic of the London Sunday Times, analyses the editing of a series of sequences in the Ealing Studio’s 1946 production of “The Overlanders”, directed by Harry Watt. Using the cattle stampede sequences as an example, she shows how the editor obtains his effects by the selection of images and sounds, and points out that the order and length of the shots create a narrative rhythm especially suited to the subject matter of the sequence.

results.title: Odd man out: a critique [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Basil Wright analyses Carol Reed’s direction in “The Odd Man Out”. He traces, with the help of blackboard illustrations, the time limits of the story in connection with the movements of Johnny (James Mason), the main character. This main storyline is impinged upon by other characters at various times, the total dramatic impulse being carried forward by these contacts with the hunted man. Mr. Wright then breaks down sequences to scenes, then to shots, underlining his reasons for claiming the title of “masterpiece” for the film. Scenes are shown ‘silent’ and the subsequent showing of a sound version demonstrates the director’s use of unseen factors and sound to lift tension.

results.title: Winners: Room to Move
results.creator_credit: John Duigan, Richard Mason, Julia Overton, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Carol is a top runner, coached by her father day and night. Then she makes friends with Angie, the new girl at school whose punk looks haven’t made her very popular. Angie introduces Carol to the wonderful world of dance, but Carol’s father won’t let her do anything that conflicts with her track-training. Parental pressure is tough on Carol who wants to succeed. She rebels and plans a new life for herself, but the all-important race is coming up and Carol has to give it all she’s got.

Cast includes Nicole Kidman, Terence Donovan and Alyssa Cook.

results.title: 3.10 to Yuma [study extract] = Three ten to Yuma
results.creator_credit: Hazel Wilkinson and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
John Freeman discusses the film “3.10 to Yuma”, an example of the “psychological western”. He illustrates three important functions of the critic; analysis, interpretation and evaluation. Shows that criticism can be both entertaining in itself, and increase the pleasure obtained from the film. He avoids talking down to his audience yet he conveys a sense of authority. He exposes the cliche, which even the serious western cannot escape, with considerable humour.

results.title: Twelve angry men [study extract]
results.creator_credit: Hazel Wilkinson and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Arnot Robertson analyses the film “Twelve Angry Men”, directed by Sidney Lumet, produced by Henry Fonda and Reginald Rose, as a ‘writer’s play’, concerened less with story and action than with character. Uses excerpts from the film to illustrate the development of the various characters and compares the opening and closing scenes.

results.title: The Tigger movie [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jun Falkenstein, Cheryl Abood and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: When no-one will play with him Tigger sets out on a journey to find his family tree, and other Tiggers. This is harder than he thought and he quickly becomes discouraged. When his friends Winnie the Pooh, Eeyore, Owl, Kanga and Roo see that their friend is sad, they pretend to be the family he wishes for, by writing him a letter and dressing up as Tiggers. But when Tigger finds out who they really are, he becomes more determined to find his real family, and wanders out into a snowstorm. Roo, upset that he has lost his best friend, convinces the others to follow Tigger and show him that they are his real family. Based on classic characters created by A.A. Milne. This animated feature length film is filled with the songs, colour and movement that young children adore.

results.title: Winners: On Loan
results.creator_credit: Anne Brooksbank, Geoffrey Bennett, Jane Scott, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
At her 14th birthday party Lindy wishes she knew her actual birth date. But only her real parents would know, and they’re both dead. Or so Lindy and her Australian family think until a letter from her natural father arrives. Now she must decide between two families and two futures, between Australia and Vietnam.

Cast includes Marillac Johnston, John Walton and Belinda Giblin.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anne Brooksbank, Geoffrey Bennett, Jane Scott, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Great expectations [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Analyses the opening scene from the Cineguild Production directed by David Lean. Shows how strong dramatic effect is achieved. Indicates in what ways the director’s treatment and editing are contrary to the expected rules.

results.title: The Tide of traffic
results.creator_credit: Derek Williams, Humphrey Swingler, British Petroleum and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Takes a world-wide look at our growing dependence on cars and road transport, and at the environmental impact of the congested motorways This film was BP’s contribution to the 1972 Stockholm United Nations Conference on the Human Environment.
